close_symbols: definition of the type/struct for OS_SharedGlobalVars (the struct tag and member declarations)
GlobalState (the member declaration inside the OS_SharedGlobalVars struct)
any typedefs used by the GlobalState member's type (e.g. uint32_t/uint32/OS_... if present)
explanation: To decide whether OS_IdleLoop violates the MISRA rule that pointers shall be const-qualified where possible, the analyzer must know the exact types and pointer-ness of the entities used in the loop and the signature of the called function: 1) OS_SharedGlobalVars (object) — the global variable referenced in the loop; we need its declaration/definition to see whether it is const-qualified, whether it is a pointer, and whether it is itself pointing to non-const data. 2) definition of the type/struct for OS_SharedGlobalVars — the struct tag and full member declarations are required to inspect GlobalState's declared type (pointer vs scalar) and any qualifiers (const/volatile). 3) GlobalState (member declaration) — the exact member type (pointer, pointer-to-pointer, or integer) and its qualifiers determine whether a const qualification is applicable or missing. 4) OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER (macro/constant definition) — to ensure the comparison is between compatible types (e.g., comparing a pointer to an integer literal could hide a pointer misuse or cast) and to see if the macro expands to an expression that involves pointers. 5) OS_IdleLoop_Impl (declaration/prototype and/or definition) — the called function might accept or return pointers; its prototype/definition is needed to check whether any pointer parameters or return values used here are missing const qualifiers. 6) any typedefs used by the GlobalState member's type (e.g. uint32_t/uint32/OS-specific typedefs) — concrete typedef definitions are needed to resolve whether GlobalState is an integer type or alias for a pointer type, and to detect any implicit pointer typedefs that affect const qualification.
